<<<<<<< HEAD
The tvvo famous pitcht battels of Lypsich, and Lutzen wherein the ever-renowned Prince Gustavus the Great lived and died a conquerour: with an elegie upon his untimely death, composed in heroick verse by John Russell, Master of Arts, of Magdalene Coll. in Cambridge. Russell, John, d. 1688. Russell, John, d. 1688. Elegie upon the death of the most illustrious and victorious Prince Gustavus Adolphus King of Swethland &c. aut
[16], 79, [1] p.
Printed by [Thomas and John Buck] the printers to the Vniversitie of Cambridge. 1634. And are to be sold by Philip Scarlet, [Cambridge] : [1634]
In verse. Printers' names from STC. "An elegie upon the immature and much lamented death of that most Christian souldier and renowned prince, Gustavus the Great", a reprint of Russell's "An elegie upon the death of the most illustrious and victorious Prince Gustavus Adolphus King of Swethland &c.", has separate dated title page; pagination and register are continuous. A variant (STC 21460.3) lacks "And are to be sold by Philip Scarlet" in imprint. Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
=======
